title: 105_hr3679
content: AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR UNITED STATES CUSTOMS SERVICE AND IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE. The United States Customs Service and Immigration and Naturalization Service are authorized appropriations for enhancing border investigative resources, anticorruption efforts, and enforcement against drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations. This includes funding for salaries, expenses, and equipment for these purposes. The United States Customs Service and Immigration and Naturalization Service are authorized appropriations for enhancing border investigative resources, anticorruption efforts, and enforcement against drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations. This includes funding for salaries, expenses, and equipment for these purposes, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 1999 and 2000, as well as subsequent years. The curr_chunk outlines funding allocations for various narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technologies along the Southwest border, including Vehicle and Container Inspection Systems, mobile truck x-rays, fixed-site truck x-ray upgrades, pallet x-rays, portable contraband detectors, contraband detection kits, and ultrasonic container inspection units. The funding allocations include $2,450,000 for automated targeting systems, $360,000 for rapid tire deflator systems, $480,000 for Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, $1,000,000 for remote watch surveillance camera systems, $1,254,000 for weigh-in-motion sensors, and $180,000 for AM radio stations at border crossings. The funding allocations for border security include $1,040,000 for inbound vehicle counters, $950,000 for spotter camera systems, $390,000 for commercial truck transponders, $1,600,000 for narcotics detectors, and $400,000 for license plate reader software. Additionally, $15,090,000 is allocated for Immigration and Naturalization Service expenses in fiscal year 1999. The funding allocation for border security includes $11,000,000 for mobile truck x-rays, $200,000 for ultrasonic container inspection units, $240,000 for Portable TECS terminals, $1,000,000 for remote watch surveillance camera systems, $175,000 for AM radio stations, and $875,000 for spotter camera systems along the Southwest land border of the United States. In addition to previous funding allocations, $1,600,000 is designated for narcotics detectors at border patrol checkpoints. For fiscal year 2000 and beyond, $4,840,400 is allocated for equipment maintenance and personnel training for Customs Service, while $1,509,000 is allocated for similar purposes for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The Commissioner of Customs may use funds allocated for equipment maintenance and training to support technologically superior equipment that achieves the same results at a lower cost. Additionally, the Commissioner can reallocate up to 10 percent of the specified amount for other equipment. In subsection (e), a specific amount is allocated for increasing inspectors and special agents on the Southwest and Northern borders during peak hours and enhancing investigative resources. The bill allocates resources for increasing inspectors and special agents at cargo facilities, drug distribution centers, and the Office of Internal Affairs to enhance investigative efforts and combat drug smuggling, money-laundering, and corruption. The bill allocates funds for increasing inspectors and canine enforcement officers at border patrol checkpoints, providing canine enforcement vehicles for inspection and enforcement at the Southwest land border, and adding intelligence analysts to border patrol sectors overseeing major drug distribution areas. The bill allocates funds for increasing resources to combat drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations, enhancing investigative resources for anticorruption efforts, and covering costs related to personnel increases.
